Package vinyl

Class Analytics

java.lang.Object
vinyl.Analytics
public class Analytics extends Object
Factory methods that create various useful analytic functions, of the form expected by SelectAPI.Window.

  • Method Details

    • fromAgg

      public static <T> BiConsumer<List<Record>,Consumer<T>> fromAgg(Collector<? super Record,?,T> collector)
      Converts an aggregate function (modeled by a Collector) to an analytic function that emits the single result of the aggregate function.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the aggregate result type
      Parameters:
      collector - the aggregate function
      Returns:
      an analytic function that emits the single result of the aggregate function

    • rowNumber

      public static BiConsumer<List<Record>,Consumer<Long>> rowNumber(long firstNumber)
      Returns an analytic function that emits a number for each record in the partition, by starting with the given first number and incrementing by one for each record.

      This analytic function generally expects input records in the partition to be pre-sorted according to some comparator.

      This analytic function behaves similar to the ROW_NUMBER function in SQL.

      Parameters:
      firstNumber - the starting number
      Returns:
      an analytic function that emits a number for each record in the partition

    • rank

      public static BiConsumer<List<Record>,Consumer<Long>> rank(long firstRank, Comparator<? super Record> comparator)
      Returns an analytic function that emits a rank for each record in the partition, by starting with the given first rank and assigning the same rank to consecutively tied records, incrementing the rank by the number of ties when the tie is broken. Consecutive records are considered tied if they compare equal using the given comparator.

      This analytic function generally expects input records in the partition to be pre-sorted according to the given comparator.

      This analytic function behaves similar to the RANK function in SQL.

      Parameters:
      firstRank - the starting rank
      comparator - a comparator used to identify ties between consecutive records
      Returns:
      an analytic function that emits a rank for each record in the partition

    • denseRank

      public static BiConsumer<List<Record>,Consumer<Long>> denseRank(long firstRank, Comparator<? super Record> comparator)
      Returns an analytic function that emits a rank for each record in the partition, by starting with the given first rank and assigning the same rank to consecutive tied records, incrementing the rank by one when the tie is broken. Consecutive records are considered tied if they compare equal using the given comparator.

      This analytic function generally expects input records in the partition to be pre-sorted according to the given comparator.

      This analytic function behaves similar to the DENSE_RANK function in SQL.

      Parameters:
      firstRank - the starting rank
      comparator - a comparator used to identify ties between consecutive records
      Returns:
      an analytic function that emits a rank for each record in the partition

    • nTile

      public static BiConsumer<List<Record>,Consumer<Long>> nTile(long firstGroup, int n)
      Returns an analytic function that distributes records in the partition into the given n number of groups.

      Group numbers are emitted by starting with the given first group number, emitting the same group number up to the group size, and then incrementing the group number by one. If the number of records in the partition is divisible by n, groups will be the same size. If the number of records in the partition is not divisible by n, the remainder will be distributed by giving earlier groups one extra member, until there is no more remainder.

      This analytic function generally expects input records in the partition to be pre-sorted according to some comparator.

      This analytic function behaves similar to the NTILE function in SQL.

      Parameters:
      firstGroup - the starting group number
      n - the number of groups
      Returns:
      an analytic function that distributes records in the partition into the given n number of groups

    • link

      public static <T> BiConsumer<List<Record>,Consumer<T>> link(Function<? super Record,? extends T> mapper, int offset, T defaultValue)
      Returns an analytic function that links each record in the partition to a value derived from another record at a given fixed offset away. The offset is added to the record index to obtain the index of the record to link to, and the given function is applied to that offset record to obtain a value to emit. If the offset index lies out of bounds, the given default value is emitted. If the offset is 0, the record links to itself.

      This analytic function generally expects input records in the partition to be pre-sorted according to some comparator.

      This analytic function behaves similar to the LEAD and LAG functions in SQL.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the linked value type
      Parameters:
      mapper - a function to be applied to each offset record to obtain a value
      offset - the fixed offset from each record index
      defaultValue - the value to emit when the offset index lies out of bounds
      Returns:
      an analytic function that links each record in the partition to a value from another record at a given fixed offset away

    • cumeDist

      public static BiConsumer<List<Record>,Consumer<Double>> cumeDist(Comparator<? super Record> comparator)
      Returns an analytic function that emits the cumulative distribution value of each record in the partition. This value is defined as the number of records preceding a record, plus consecutively succeeding tied records, all divided by the total number of records. Consecutive records are considered tied if they compare equal using the given comparator. The cumulative distribution value is always greater than 0 and less than or equal to 1.

      This analytic function generally expects input records in the partition to be pre-sorted according to the given comparator. This makes the cumulative distribution value of a record equal to the number of records with values less than or equal to the value of that record, divided by the total number of records.

      This analytic function behaves similar to the CUME_DIST function in SQL.

      Parameters:
      comparator - a comparator used to identify ties between consecutive records
      Returns:
      an analytic function that emits the cumulative distribution value of each record in the partition

    • percentRank

      public static BiConsumer<List<Record>,Consumer<Double>> percentRank(Comparator<? super Record> comparator)
      Returns an analytic function that emits the percent rank value of each record in the partition. This value is defined as the number of records preceding a record, minus consecutively preceding tied records, all divided by one less than the total number of records. Consecutive records are considered tied if they compare equal using the given comparator. The percent rank value is always greater than or equal to 0 and less than or equal to 1. The first record in any partition always has a percent rank of 0.

      This analytic function generally expects input records in the partition to be pre-sorted according to the given comparator. This makes the percent rank value of a record equal to the number of records with values less than the value of that record, divided by one less than the total number of records.

      This analytic function behaves similar to the PERCENT_RANK function in SQL.

      Parameters:
      comparator - a comparator used to identify ties between consecutive records
      Returns:
      an analytic function that emits the cumulative distribution value of each record in the partition

    • percentileDisc

      public static <T> BiConsumer<List<Record>,Consumer<T>> percentileDisc(double percentile, Function<? super Record,? extends T> mapper)
      Returns an analytic function that emits one value for the partition, derived from the record that is positioned closest to the given percentile's index. More specifically, the percentile is multiplied by the last index in the partition, yielding an exact percentile index. Then a value is emitted by applying the given function to the record whose index is closest to the percentile index.

      The given percentile must be greater than or equal to 0 and less than or equal to 1, otherwise an IllegalArgumentException is thrown.

      This analytic function generally expects input records in the partition to be pre-sorted according to a comparator that compares records based on the value that would be returned by applying the given function to the record.

      This analytic function behaves similar to the PERCENTILE_DISC function in SQL.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the value type
      Parameters:
      percentile - the percentile
      mapper - a function to be applied to the record closest to the percentile index
      Returns:
      an analytic function that emits one value for the partition, based on a discontinuous interpretation of the percentile
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the given percentile is less than 0 or greater than 1

    • percentileCont

      public static BiConsumer<List<Record>,Consumer<Double>> percentileCont(double percentile, Function<? super Record,? extends Number> mapper)
      Returns an analytic function that emits one value for the partition, derived by interpolation from the values of the records that are positioned closest on either side of the given percentile's index. More specifically, the percentile is multiplied by the last index in the partition, yielding an exact percentile index. Then a value is emitted by applying the given function to the two records on either side of the percentile index, and interpolating a value between them based on the relative distance from the percentile index to each record index. If the percentile index is a mathematical integer, then interpolation can be skipped, as the percentile index will exactly match a single record index.

      The given percentile must be greater than or equal to 0 and less than or equal to 1, otherwise an IllegalArgumentException is thrown.

      This analytic function generally expects input records in the partition to be pre-sorted according to a comparator that compares records based on the value that would be returned by applying the given function to the record.

      This analytic function behaves similar to the PERCENTILE_CONT function in SQL.

      Parameters:
      percentile - the percentile
      mapper - a function to be applied to the records closest to the percentile index
      Returns:
      an analytic function that emits one value for the partition, based on a continuous interpretation of the percentile
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the given percentile is less than 0 or greater than 1
